subject: History
title: Penicillin's Accidental Discovery
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Penicillin's Accidental Discovery.

hook.text: A messy scientist left a petri dish uncovered. The mold that grew on it would save 200 million lives.

buildup.text: In 1928, Alexander Fleming noticed mold killing bacteria in his lab. He called the substance penicillin.

discovery.text: Fleming couldn't purify enough penicillin to be useful. It took Florey and Chain a decade to mass-produce it.

twist.text: By D-Day in 1944, the Allies had enough penicillin to treat every wounded soldier. It was the war's secret weapon.

climax.text: Penicillin launched the antibiotic era. Infections that once meant death became treatable overnight.

punchline.text: A dirty dish changed the course of medicine.

quiz.question: Why couldn't Fleming alone bring penicillin to patients?
options: He didn't realize its medical potential
He couldn't purify and mass-produce enough of it
The British government classified it as a military secret
